tern 0.5.0.1
  • Reference
  • Changelog

Adverse Events Table by Highest NCI CTCAE Grade

t_ae_ctc.Rd

t_ae_ctc returns adverse events sorted by highest NCI (National Cancer Institute) CTCAE (common terminology criteria for adverse avents) grade.

t_ae_ctc(class, term, id, grade, col_by, total = "All Patients",
  grade_levels = 1:5)

Arguments

class

system organ class variable.
term

preferred term variable.
id

unique subject identifier variable. If a particular subject has no adverse event then the subject id should be listed where class and term should be set to missing (i.e. NA).
grade

grade of adverse event variable.
col_by

group variable that will be used for a column header. col_by has to be a factor and can not be missing. See 'Examples'.
total

character string that will be used as a label for a column with pooled total population, default is "All Patients".
grade_levels

ordered values of possible of grades in a form of x:y, default is 1:5. This assures a proper fill in for grades, see 'Details'.

Details

t_ae_ctc counts patients according to adverse events (AEs) of greatest intensity for system organ class (SOC) and overall rows and includes percentages based on the total number of patients in the column heading (i.e. "N=nnn"). If the intention is to use patients number from subject level dataset as N for percentage calculation then adeverse events dataset should be left joined to subject level dataset and the col_by variable should be dropped from adverse events dataset, see the example. Otherwise, N will be derived using adverse events dataset. At the preferred term (PT) level, multiple events within a patient of the same PT are counted once using the greatest intensity reported.

t_ae_ctc removes any non-complete records, e.g. if class or term are missing. If the intent is to preserve such records, then impute missing values before using t_ae_ctc.

t_ae_ctc orders data by "All Patients" column from the most commonly reported SOC to the least frequent one. Within SOC, it sorts by decreasing frequency of PT. It brakes ties using SOC/PT names in alphabetical order.

t_ae_ctc fills in col_by and grade with 0 value in case there was no AEs reported for particular col_by and/or grade category. Use grade_levels to modify the range of existing grades. If data does not have any records with grade 5 and the intent is to show only grades 1-4 rows then use grade_levels = 1:4.

Examples

# Simple example
library(tibble)
library(dplyr)

ASL <- tibble(
  USUBJID = paste0("id-", 1:10),
  ARM = paste("ARM", LETTERS[rep(c(1,2), c(3,7))])
)


ae_lookup <- tribble(
  ~CLASS,         ~TERM,   ~GRADE,
  "cl A",   "trm A_1/2",        1,
  "cl A",   "trm A_2/2",        2,
  "cl B",   "trm B_1/3",        2,
  "cl B",   "trm B_2/3",        3,
  "cl B",   "trm B_3/3",        1,
  "cl C",   "trm C_1/1",        1
)

AAE <- cbind(
  tibble(
    USUBJID = ASL$USUBJID[c(2,2,2,3,3,4,4,4,4,5,6,6,7,7)]
  ),
  ae_lookup[c(1,1,2,6,4,2,2,3,4,2,1,5,4,6),]
)

ANL <- left_join(ASL, AAE, by = "USUBJID")

tbl <- t_ae_ctc(
  class = ANL$CLASS,
  term =  ANL$TERM,
  id = ANL$USUBJID,
  grade = ANL$GRADE,
  col_by = factor(ANL$ARM),
  total = "All Patients",
  grade_levels = 1:3
)
#> Error in rrowl("", if (is.no_by(col_by_var)) nrow(x) else lapply(col_data,     nrow), format = col_total): object 'col_total' not found

tbl
#> function (src, ...) 
#> {
#>     UseMethod("tbl")
#> }
#> <environment: namespace:dplyr>


library(random.cdisc.data)
library(dplyr)

ASL <- radam("ASL", N = 10)
AAE <- radam("AAE", ADSL = ASL)

ANL <- left_join(AAE, ASL %>% select(USUBJID, STUDYID, ARM), by = c("STUDYID", "USUBJID"))

tbl <- with(ANL,
            t_ae_ctc(
              class = AEBODSYS,
              term =  AEDECOD,
              id = USUBJID,
              grade = AETOXGR,
              col_by = factor(ARM),
              total = "All Patients",
              grade_levels = 1:5
            )
)
#> Error in rrowl("", if (is.no_by(col_by_var)) nrow(x) else lapply(col_data,     nrow), format = col_total): object 'col_total' not found
